articles.headline: How Cooper Union’s Endowment Failed in Its Mission
articles.snippet: Cooper Union recently announced that it would begin charging tuition, a decision made after decades of bad financial choices and recent treacherous markets.
articles.abstract: Cooper Union recently announced that it would begin charging tuition, a decision made after decades of bad financial choices and recent treacherous markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Peter Cooper’s heirs gave the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art the land under the Chrysler Building in 1902, the school’s endowment has enabled it to offer students a high-quality, tuition-free education through two world wars, the Great Depression and multiple stock market crashes and financial crises.

articles.headline: The Trek to a Yogurt Less Sweet
articles.snippet: Dannon cut the sugar in its Danimals Smoothies for children, but it did so with the utmost care to make sure children couldn’t taste the difference.
articles.abstract: Dannon cut the sugar in its Danimals Smoothies for children, but it did so with the utmost care to make sure children couldn’t taste the difference.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — Dannon yogurt had a secret it didn’t want you to know. Until recently.

articles.headline: Rebuilding After Sandy, but With Costly New Rules
articles.snippet: A new law will cause flood insurance premiums to skyrocket and require stricter, and thus more expensive, rebuilding standards.
articles.abstract: A new law will cause flood insurance premiums to skyrocket and require stricter, and thus more expensive, rebuilding standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been more than six months since Hurricane Sandy hit the East Coast, yet many people whose homes were ravaged by the storm still do not know how to put all the pieces back together.

articles.headline: Privacy Breach on Bloomberg’s Data Terminals
articles.snippet: Bloomberg News confirmed that reporters for its news service used the the company’s terminals to monitor subscribers’ usage.
articles.abstract: Bloomberg News confirmed that reporters for its news service used the the company’s terminals to monitor subscribers’ usage.
articles.lead_paragraph: A shudder went through Wall Street on Friday after the revelation that Bloomberg News reporters had extracted subscribers’ private information through the company’s ubiquitous data terminals to break news.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Retailers Are Pressed on Safety at Factories
articles.snippet: Organizations have been growing impatient because only two companies have signed onto a binding agreement on safety standards for factories in Bangladesh.
articles.abstract: Organizations have been growing impatient because only two companies have signed onto a binding agreement on safety standards for factories in Bangladesh.
articles.lead_paragraph: A wide spectrum of government officials, investors and religious groups are warning major retailers like Walmart, Benetton and Gap that they could face financial repercussions from consumers, damage to their stock value or sustained public protests if they do not adopt stricter garment manufacturing standards.

articles.headline: China Officials Seek Career Shortcut With Feng Shui
articles.snippet: China’s ambitious civil servants are increasingly — if discreetly — seeking supernatural shortcuts to wealth and power, much to the dismay of the Communist Party.
articles.abstract: China’s ambitious civil servants are increasingly — if discreetly — seeking supernatural shortcuts to wealth and power, much to the dismay of the Communist Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZOUMAJIE, China — Outraged peasants protesting land grabs. Jilted mistresses plotting revenge. Provincial investigators seeking out graft.

articles.headline: Benghazi E-Mails Put White House on the Defensive
articles.snippet: A disclosure of e-mails showed the White House was more involved in revising talking points about the attack in Benghazi, Libya, than officials have previously acknowledged.
articles.abstract: A disclosure of e-mails showed the White House was more involved in revising talking points about the attack in Benghazi, Libya, than officials have previously acknowledged.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A long-simmering dispute over the White House’s account of the deadly assault on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, flared up on Friday, with a disclosure of e-mails that show the White House was more deeply involved in revising talking points about the attack than officials have previously acknowledged.

articles.headline: Trying to Be Hip and Edgy, Ads Become Offensive
articles.snippet: Some of the biggest names in marketing have had to apologize after consumers objected to ads that hinged on race, rape and suicide.
articles.abstract: Some of the biggest names in marketing have had to apologize after consumers objected to ads that hinged on race, rape and suicide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Madison Avenue is learning a painful lesson: cutting edge advertising can slice both ways.
articles.byline: By Stuart Elliott and Tanzina Vega

articles.headline: Ex-Premier Is Set to Regain Power in Pakistan Vote
articles.snippet: The party led by former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, once a political exile, appeared to have enough seats to form a government easily.
articles.abstract: The party led by former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, once a political exile, appeared to have enough seats to form a government easily.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, once a political exile deposed by the military, returned to the cusp of power on Saturday, taking a commanding lead in a parliamentary election in which Pakistanis braved Taliban intimidation to cast ballots with historic prospects for the country’s democracy.

articles.headline: Directors Disappoint by What They Don’t Do
articles.snippet: While JPMorgan Chase is drawing scrutiny, errors and omissions by other companies’ boards also let shareholders down.
articles.abstract: While JPMorgan Chase is drawing scrutiny, errors and omissions by other companies’ boards also let shareholders down.
articles.lead_paragraph: DIRECTORS of some high-profile public companies are coming under scrutiny this proxy season. Shareholder advocates say it’s about time.

articles.headline: The Long Shadow of Bad Credit in a Job Search
articles.snippet: Many companies, especially some retailers, use an applicant’s credit report in making hiring decisions.
articles.abstract: Many companies, especially some retailers, use an applicant’s credit report in making hiring decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE first couple of times Alfred J. Carpenter was turned down for a job, he didn’t know what to think.

articles.headline: The Mellowing of Maxine Waters
articles.snippet: Since becoming the top Democrat on the House Financial Services Committee, Representative Maxine Waters has softened her tone and vowed to protect bankers’ interests.
articles.abstract: Since becoming the top Democrat on the House Financial Services Committee, Representative Maxine Waters has softened her tone and vowed to protect bankers’ interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

articles.headline: Some Countries Lobby for More in Race for Visas
articles.snippet: The prospect of immigration overhaul has spurred energetic lobbying from many foreign nations seeking a little something extra, whether additional work permits or visa-free tourist visits.
articles.abstract: The prospect of immigration overhaul has spurred energetic lobbying from many foreign nations seeking a little something extra, whether additional work permits or visa-free tourist visits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The government of South Korea hired a former C.I.A. analyst, two White House veterans and a team of ex-Congressional staff members to help secure a few paragraphs in the giant immigration bill.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Delays on Nominees Raise Tension
articles.snippet: After Republicans used Senate rules to block two nominees in committee despite majority support, Democrats are planning to force committee votes without Republican consent.
articles.abstract: After Republicans used Senate rules to block two nominees in committee despite majority support, Democrats are planning to force committee votes without Republican consent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s latest cabinet-level nominees are running into deep resistance in the Senate, pitching Democrats and Republicans into another tense standoff over White House appointments.

articles.headline: I.R.S. Focus on Conservatives Gives G.O.P. an Issue to Seize On
articles.snippet: The Internal Revenue Service’s special scrutiny went beyond keyword hunts for organizations with “Tea Party” or “patriot” in their names, to a more overtly ideological search.
articles.abstract: The Internal Revenue Service’s special scrutiny went beyond keyword hunts for organizations with “Tea Party” or “patriot” in their names, to a more overtly ideological search.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service’s special scrutiny of small-government groups applying for tax-exempt status went beyond keyword hunts for organizations with “Tea Party” or “Patriot” in their names, to a more overtly ideological search for applicants seeking to “make America a better place to live” or “criticize how the country is being run,” according to part of a draft audit by the inspector general that has been given to Capitol Hill.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: In Taiwan, Lamenting a Lost Lead
articles.snippet: Fostering innovation has become a mantra among corporate leaders and government officials because Taiwan’s huge consumer electronics industry has run into serious trouble.
articles.abstract: Fostering innovation has become a mantra among corporate leaders and government officials because Taiwan’s huge consumer electronics industry has run into serious trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Jonney Shih, the chairman of Asustek Computer, has epitomized the Taiwanese electronics engineer for a generation: a slender figure in rumpled, baggy trousers, he once helped Intel solve heat problems in its Pentium 4 microprocessors.

articles.headline: ABC to Live-Stream Its Shows via App
articles.snippet: The live stream, which will be available only to cable and satellite subscribers, is the first time that any major broadcaster has turned on such a technology.
articles.abstract: The live stream, which will be available only to cable and satellite subscribers, is the first time that any major broadcaster has turned on such a technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week ABC will quietly revolutionize its app for iPhones and iPads with a button called “live.” Users around New York and Philadelphia will be able to live-stream all the programming from ABC’s local stations there, the first time that any major broadcaster has turned on such a technology.

articles.headline: Big Vote on Dimon May Hinge on Views on JPMorgan’s Top Director
articles.snippet: A shareholder vote on whether to split Jamie Dimon’s roles as chief executive and chairman could turn on whether the board’s lead director, Lee Raymond, is seen as strong enough to stand up to Mr. Dimon.
articles.abstract: A shareholder vote on whether to split Jamie Dimon’s roles as chief executive and chairman could turn on whether the board’s lead director, Lee Raymond, is seen as strong enough to stand up to Mr. Dimon.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his 12 years as chief executive of Exxon Mobil, Lee R. Raymond had a reputation for bulldozing analysts and long-winded shareholders and going toe-to-toe with government authorities.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Sophomore Slump Afflicts Once-Promising TV Shows
articles.snippet: Some of the most popular new series from a year ago declined in the ratings in their second seasons.
articles.abstract: Some of the most popular new series from a year ago declined in the ratings in their second seasons.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last thing network television needs is a sophomore slump.

articles.headline: Newspaper Monopoly That Lost Its Grip
articles.snippet: The New Orleans Times-Picayune announced it would return to producing a printed product every day after losing both readers and advertisers and gaining competition.
articles.abstract: The New Orleans Times-Picayune announced it would return to producing a printed product every day after losing both readers and advertisers and gaining competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after announcing a plan to reorganize The Times-Picayune of New Orleans into a more digitally focused enterprise that produced a newspaper just three days a week — enraging local residents — its owners have added a new innovation: they will go back to producing a printed product every day.

articles.headline: San Diego Mayor Building Economic Bridges to Tijuana
articles.snippet: Mayor Bob Filner sees the border as a potential economic engine for the region, a remarkable shift in a city once viewed as a hotbed for illegal immigration.
articles.abstract: Mayor Bob Filner sees the border as a potential economic engine for the region, a remarkable shift in a city once viewed as a hotbed for illegal immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Opening a satellite city office in a far-flung neighborhood is not unusual in sprawling cities like this one. But one thing sets apart Mayor Bob Filner’s newest outpost: it is in another country.

articles.headline: Chinese Creating New Auto Niche Within Detroit
articles.snippet: Dozens of companies from China are quietly planting roots in Detroit, investing in American businesses and new vehicle technology in what is seen as a first step toward the sale of Chinese cars in the United States.
articles.abstract: Dozens of companies from China are quietly planting roots in Detroit, investing in American businesses and new vehicle technology in what is seen as a first step toward the sale of Chinese cars in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Dozens of companies from China are putting down roots in Detroit, part of the country’s steady push into the American auto industry.

articles.headline: As TV Ratings and Profits Fall, Networks Face a Cliffhanger
articles.snippet: The broadcast networks are preparing to unveil new fall lineups for an audience that is shrinking rapidly, lured away by new rivals on all sides.
articles.abstract: The broadcast networks are preparing to unveil new fall lineups for an audience that is shrinking rapidly, lured away by new rivals on all sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the major television networks prepare to unveil their new fall lineups in New York this week, they face threats from seemingly every corner.

articles.headline: Walters to Announce 2014 Retirement on ‘The View’
articles.snippet: Network television’s first anchorwoman plans to announce Monday that next year she will leave the business where she broke barriers and rules for more than 50 years.
articles.abstract: Network television’s first anchorwoman plans to announce Monday that next year she will leave the business where she broke barriers and rules for more than 50 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the program she invented, on the network where she worked for the past 37 years, on the medium where she broke barriers and rules for more than 50 years, Barbara Walters will announce on Monday morning, definitively and with no regrets, that she is calling it a career.

articles.headline: Bloomberg Admits Terminal Snooping
articles.snippet: Reporters at Bloomberg News were told to use the terminals to get an edge in the competitive world of financial journalism, more than half a dozen former employees said.
articles.abstract: Reporters at Bloomberg News were told to use the terminals to get an edge in the competitive world of financial journalism, more than half a dozen former employees said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reporters at Bloomberg News were trained to use a function on the company’s financial data terminals that allowed them to view subscribers’ contact information and, in some cases, monitor login activity in order to advance news coverage, more than half a dozen former employees said.

articles.headline: Global Retailers Join Safety Plan for Bangladesh
articles.snippet: Under mounting pressure, several companies agreed to a landmark plan to help pay for safety improvements in Bangladesh’s garment factories.
articles.abstract: Under mounting pressure, several companies agreed to a landmark plan to help pay for safety improvements in Bangladesh’s garment factories.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under mounting pressure to improve working conditions in Bangladesh’s garment factories, several of the world’s largest apparel companies agreed on Monday to a landmark plan to help pay for fire safety and building improvements after the collapse last month of the Rana Plaza factory complex, which killed more than 1,100 people.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Jim Yardley
